description.narrative: The Water Integrity Network - WIN - is an action-oriented coalition of organizations and individuals that promote water integrity for reducing and preventing corruption water sector WIN's members include public and private sectors, civil societ and others. WIN is funded by Germany/BMZ, Netherlands/DGIS, Sweden/SIDA & Switzerland/SDC.

Titel Kärnstöd till Water Integrity Network (WIN) Association 2014 - 2017 Core support to the Water Integrity Network (WIN) Association 2014 - 2017
Använda förkortningar: DGIS Directorate-General for International Cooperation, NL GWP Global Water Partnership IHE Institute for Water Education IRC International Rescue Committee SAGE Business management software product SDC Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation SIWI Stockholm International Water Institute WASH Water, Sanitation and Hygiene WIN Water Integrity Network Association
WINs målsättning är att öka integriteten och minska korruptionen i vattensektorn genom att anta ett fattigdoms- och jämnlikhetsfokus. WIN har utvecklat en ansats där de arbetar på olika nivåer med beslutsfattare på global, regional och lokal nivå, med globala och lokala organisationer/NGOs och andra lokala grupper och professionella aktörer för att öka kunskapen om korruption inom vattensektorn, dela information och metoder för att bekämpa korruption och sätta ämnet på den internationella agendan. Genom att arbeta både med den statliga och privata sektorn samt civila samhället vill WIN påverka beslutsfattare att främja arbete med frågan och bygga kapacitet för användandet av verktyg och metoder för ökad vatten integritet på alla nivåer. För att nå sitt övergripande mål har WIN delat upp sitt arbete i fyra målområden 1. Att öka medvetenheten om vattenrelaterad korruption och hävda vikten av aktion. Inom det här målområdet kommer WIN att bygga starka partnerskap med organisationer från olika bakgrunder, verksamma inom vattenområdet. Detta för att skapa en plattform där olika intressen blir representerade och information utbyts för att hitta gemensamma lösningar för att motarbeta korruption inom vattensektorn. WIN vill här skapa ett starkt nätverk där vattenkorruption kommer upp på agendan på internationella konferenser, möten och integreras i organisationer aktiva inom vatten. 2. Att hjälpa till och tänka ut, uppmuntra och stödja samarbeten och program för att öka integriteten i vattensektorn och hantera korruption på ett välplanerat och målinriktat sätt. Inom detta målområde syftar WIN främst till att belysa och kartlägga korruption inom vatten. Genom att föra samman olika aktörer inom området uppmuntrar nätverket till ett utbyte av information, erfarenheter och nya perspektiv. Detta ämnar inte minst till att bygga kapacitet samt till att informera och erbjuda verktyg till lokala och nationella aktörer om hur man effektivt kan arbeta mot korruption inom vatten. 3. Uppmuntra användandet av verktyg och metoder för att utvärdera korruption, förbättra integriteten och förvaltningen av vattenresurser. WIN ämnar här vidareutveckla verktyg och metoder som testats och bevisats framgångsrika. Verktygen och metoderna sprids sedan inom nätverket och till andra aktörer genom WINs hemsida, informationsmanualer och events. 4. Förbättra effektiviteten inom organisationen för att kunna vara en ledande aktör med ett anti-korruptionsfokus som arbetar för att öka vattenintegritet globalt. WIN är en relativt liten organisation som nyligen blivit självständig från Transparency International och som organisation har de ambitionen att höja kapaciteten både internt och externt hos partner organisationer för att effektivt kunna arbeta med övriga målområden.
To increase integrity levels and reduce corruption in the water sector through a pro-poor and pro-equity focus.

description.narrative: WIN aims to increase integrity and reduce corruption through working in partnerships with other organisations in the water sector both national and international. The ambition is to bring water integrity on the international and national agendas. Through the partnerships and the information sharing (of perceived corruption and efficient methods and tools to prevent and fight corruption) national and international organisations are empowered to develop their own action plans to prevent and fight corruption. The small WIN secretariat can by this logic of work reach a wide audience and achieve a great impact globally. WIN developed a new strategy from 2017 to 2022, thus Sida’s final year of support for our first phase is WINs first year of a new strategic period. WIN produced a final report for the strategy period 2011-2016 that is called “Lessons learned from water integrity action under WIN’s strategy 2011–2016” and was launched in March 2018. The report provides insights on work that the network has led, supported, and documented. A prime message is that the most affected (i.e. poor and marginalized communities) typically are unable to speak out about corruption, why such undue practice needs to attain more profound public attention. Yet in working to prevent corruption and increase integrity in the water sector, WIN notes that adaptive language and method is key and that change takes time. Gradually push the borders of work, be sensitive to culture and context, establish trust, form alliances and strategic partnerships – such practical insight resonate among a total 12 ‘lessons learned’ that are instrumental in guiding implementation of the current strategy (2017-2022). 2017 was the first year of our new WIN strategy 2017 – 2022, Engaging with partners for change. The change that WIN aims to enable is increased integrity and reduced corruption in the water sector, so not only resources are used efficiently, but trust is enhanced to attract sufficient funding for meeting the challenges of SDG 6 and realizing the human rights to water and sanitation. As part of WIN’s objective to put integrity more strongly on the agenda of international water sector organizations, interactions with international partners resulted in six organizations making explicit commitments to water integrity in their strategies, policies or annual work plans. Two partners, the IADB and KfW, started or continued integrating water integrity into their investment programmes in Latin America and Albania respectively. A strong focus in the new strategy is to carry out activities in WIN’s three focus countries: Benin, Bangladesh, and Kenya. In Bangladesh, for example, a study was completed on integrity issues in the use of Effluent Treatment Plants in the Garments Industry. In Kenya, the Water Sector Trust Fund’s risk management framework and policy were reviewed based on WIN’s recommendations, and now include effective integrity and risk management practices. In Benin, a baseline study identified integrity risks and levels in the sector to inform future reforms and initiatives and facilitate measuring of results. As concerns results during WINs first phase 2011-2016, one milestone was the publication of Water Integrity Global Outlook (WIGO) in 2016. The report captures a growing recognition of the need for good governance and measures to eliminate corruption to improve sector performance. WIGO highlights how institutional fragmentation and corruption undermine resources and services. It outlines techniques that make improvements achievable and makes recommendations for action by governments, sector actors, the private sector and civil society bodies. The report was developed by WIN in partnership with CapNet, the Global Water Partnership, Transparency International, Transparency International Bangladesh, BAWIN, the Water Governance Facility, and SIWI. The report was for example used by AMCOW in Dar Es Salaam Roadmap to reach N’Gor Commitments for water security and sanitation in Africa. The report can be used both as a benchmark, a reference document and an inspiration for future work in the area. Before the new strategy the country programme included support to more countries than the current strategy. Results from these include: - Bangladesh (implementing partners: Bangladesh Water Integrity Network, hosted by Transparency International Bangladesh): Khulna Water and Sewerage Authority reduces its water connection time by 30% after launching the implementation of its integrity roadmap using the Integrity Management toolbox. - Benin Implementing partners: GWP-PNE Benin (Global Water Partnership – Partenariat National de l’Eau du Benin)): Water sector stakeholders endorse the Water Integrity Charter at the annual joint water sector review and outline plans to practically develop measures to make the charter operational. - Ethiopia (implementing partners: GOWIN programme set up in collaboration with the Ministry of Water Irrigation & Energy, the Awash Basin Authority, and the Dutch Regional Water Authorities): The Ethiopian Ministry of Water, Irrigation and Electricity confirmed its willingness to co-convene a sub-regional Water Integrity Forum in 2017 in Addis Ababa. - Kenya (implementing partners: CESPAD, KEWASNET, CARITAS Switzerland): Kenyan water service regulators and water resource management authorities explore possibility of anchoring capacity development and integrity management tools for community managed water systems and water resources user associations respectively, following pilot tool implementations. - Mozambique (implementing partners: HELVETAS CFPAS): The Budget Monitoring Forum (BMF) successfully advocates for a strengthened parliamentary review and external audit of hidden debts and for protecting the WASH sector from budget cuts.
